raw_text:
US 'afflicted' with awards fatigue
 
 The film world and media may be wild about the Oscars but cinema-goers and the TV-viewing public are sick of watching award ceremonies, according to some LA film critics.
 
 Bob Strauss, from the LA Daily News, thinks there are just too many televised gatherings of stars showering praise on each other. He came up with a colourful but unprintable description for these glitzy events, which roughly translates a "celebrity love-in". This echoed the views of Oscars host and comedian Chris Rock, who whipped up a media storm for saying he rarely watched them, calling award shows "idiotic". "As Chris Rock accurately said, they're about celebrity and fashion," Mr Strauss said. The recent Grammy music awards proved to be a ratings loser, and it seems Oscars organisers are determined not to go the same way.
 
 Recently announced changes to the ceremony include lining up all five nominees on stage before announcing the winner.
 
 Unsurprisingly, this prompted press speculation that the changes were aimed at boosting flagging advertising revenue. But Entertainment Weekly's Dave Karger maintained the Oscars only generated excitement outside the industry when a blockbuster, such as Titanic or Lord of the Rings, was nominated. The near constant flow of US film awards, representing directors, actors and producers' guilds, also means "few surprises" are left by the time the Oscar ceremony is upon us, he said. A quick scan of the Los Angeles Times and Los Angeles Daily News bears this out - speculation about who will win seems to have ground to a halt.
 
 On Thursday, the Times simply printed a picture of the plastic tents going up outside the Kodak Theatre to protect the red carpet from rain. Variety and the Hollywood Reporter have also kept their focus firmly on industry-related news, while in the UK bets have closed on the best actor category, with Ray star Jamie Foxx a dead cert to win.
 
 Screen International's US editor Mike Goodridge thinks 2004's films have simply not grabbed the public's imagination. "Film-makers haven't produced films that people adore this year," he said. "They adored Saving Private Ryan for example - people loved it and it made a ton of money. "2004's films could be a reaction to 9/11 - there was a realisation in America that things might not be so rosy after all. "Audiences don't necessarily want to see darker films such as Million Dollar Baby, Aviator and Finding Neverland, which end with casualty." As to whether Rock could pep up the awards, the critics were not hopeful.
 
 Mr Strauss doubted whether Rock would make an impact, but added: "I'm all for lower ratings though - there are far more important things going on than the Oscars." Mr Karger said the comic might boost younger viewers, but Mike Goodridge thought Rock's humour could prompt America's conservative states to switch off. So despite all this, did the critics have any views on who would win?
 
 "Clint Eastwood's Million Dollar Baby affected people emotionally, which is why it will beat Aviator, which was about technical artistry not feelings," Mr Karger said. "Eastwood has it in the bag," added Mr Strauss. "Oscar voters often vote with their hearts not their heads." And Mr Goodridge said best film and director were between Martin Scorsese's Aviator and Million Dollar Baby. Mr Karger, whose favourite film of the year was Mike Leigh's abortion drama Vera Drake, stayed upbeat about the awards despite his other comments. "I hope this is the year for small films to triumph," he said. "After all, it's still one of the biggest TV events of the year."
llama3.2:1b: US film critics are saying that they're tired of watching award ceremonies on television, calling them a "celebrity love-in" and saying that audiences are no longer interested in seeing films nominated for Oscars.
The recent Grammy music awards were considered a ratings loser, leading some to speculate about why the Oscars might be changing its format.

Variety's Dave Karger said that while the Oscars only generate excitement outside of the industry when a blockbuster is nominated, and the near constant flow of US film awards means few surprises are left by the time the ceremony is upon us.
llama3.2:3b: US film critics say Oscars are too long and focus on celebrity glamour rather than good films, with some speculating that hosting comedian Chris Rock could boost ratings but others think his humour might alienate conservative viewers.
gemma2:2b: Award ceremonies are becoming tiresome for audiences, who see them as nothing more than a celebrity show.
The recent changes to the Oscars, such as presenting nominees on stage before revealing the winner, have been met with speculation that the aim is financial gain.
However, some believe these changes are merely a desperate attempt to boost excitement in an industry where awards season has left viewers uninspired.
Several critics express disappointment in 2004's films' lack of widespread appeal, and wonder if Chris Rock will be able to inject much-needed energy into the ceremony.
Despite this pessimism, experts still believe Clint Eastwood's "Million Dollar Baby" and Martin Scorsese's "Aviator" are strong contenders for the top awards.
qwen2.5:0.5b: US critics are sick of watching award ceremonies and are looking forward to the Oscars instead (article from Entertainment Weekly).
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Oscars have reached a point where most people find award ceremonies boring and uninteresting due to excessive repetition of similar award shows.
Awards fatigue has become an issue in Hollywood with critics expecting fewer surprises at the Academy Awards this year compared to previous years.

The industry is turning its attention away from high-profile events like the Oscars, focusing instead on other areas such as movie reviews and news about actors' performances that are more relevant to everyday people.

US 'afflicted' with awards fatigue

Bob Strauss from LA Daily News calls these glitzy events a "celebrity love-in," echoing Chris Rock's opinion that award shows are about celebrity and fashion.

Recent changes aim to boost advertising revenue, though Entertainment Weekly suggests it's because few surprises remain as US film awards generate excitement only for blockbuster nominations like Titanic or Lord of the Rings.
The Oscars have struggled with lower ratings due to lackluster films from 2004, which viewers prefer not to see after 9/11.
Mike Goodridge posits that audiences are unlikely to be excited by darker films such as Million Dollar Baby, Aviator, and Finding Neverland.
While Chris Rock's humor may attract younger viewers, his comments also worry critics like Mike Goodridge about potential conservative backlash in the US.
Critics predict Clint Eastwood’s "Million Dollar Baby" will win over Christopher Nolan's "The Dark Knight," though there is a debate between Martin Scorsese's "Ray" and "A.I."
Despite overall pessimism, some maintain hope that smaller films might succeed this year.

smollm:1.7b:

1.
The US film industry is plagued with awards fatigue, leading to a decline in ratings.
Bob Strauss, from the LA Daily News, thinks there are too many televised gatherings of stars showering praise on each other.
Chris Rock's comments indicate that he rarely watches Oscars and believes they're about celebrity and fashion rather than entertainment.
The recent Grammy music awards have been a ratings loser for the industry as a whole, which may be contributing to the decline in Oscars attendance.
Unsurprisingly, this prompted press speculation that the changes are aimed at boosting advertising revenue.
A quick scan of the Los Angeles Times and Los Angeles Daily News bears this out - coverage of the Oscars is focused on industry-related news rather than entertainment news.
Variety and the Hollywood Reporter have kept their focus firmly on industry-related news, while in the UK bets have closed on the best actor category for 2004's films.
Screen International's US editor Mike Goodridge thinks 2004's films have not grabbed the public's imagination as much as they did in 1999 and 2003.
Mr Karger believes that Rock's humor could prompt America's conservative states to switch off, which may contribute to the decline in Oscars attendance.
Despite all this, did the critics have any views on who would win?

The article concludes by summarizing the main ideas and key points of the text, highlighting the negative impact of awards fatigue on ratings and the potential for small films to triumph over big-budget blockbusters.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The film industry has faced a period of awards fatigue, feeling overwhelmed by the pressure to perform at top levels.
Los Angeles film critics expressed concern over televised gatherings of celebrities praising each other, fearing it may be a sign of the awards fatigue they've been facing.
Bob Strauss introduced a metaphorical "celebrity love-in" to describe these events, similar to Chris Rock's media storm when he mentioned rarely watching them.
The recent Grammy music awards further eroded excitement by being seen as less exciting than expected.

Recent changes in ceremonies, such as lining up all five nominees on stage before announcing the winner, have sparked press speculation, with industry leaders aiming for a boost in advertising revenue.
However, the industry itself remains unaffected by these gatherings, as the constant flow of awards from various sources gives "few surprises."
In Los Angeles, press-ups focused on industry-related news, while in the UK, bets closed on the best actor category, leaving audiences with uncertainty.
Mike Goodridge, US film editor, noted that 2004 films haven't grabbed public imagination due to their emotional impact.
However, critics pointed out that audiences may not care about darker films like million dollar baby but prefer emotional reactions.
Rock's humor was seen as hopeful, yet critics doubted his impact.
In the UK, award ceremonies are being closed on the best actor category with Jamie Foxx as a likely winner.
Clint Eastwood's Million Dollar Baby won emotionally, overshadowing Aviator by its impact on public opinion.
Strauss thought voters often make strong emotional decisions despite their heads, while Goodridge suggested that it could be between Aviator and million dollar baby for best film/director.
Spacey was considered a winner, though other critics were skeptical.

In summary, the film industry faces awards fatigue, reacts negatively to ceremonies with "few surprises," focuses on industry matters, and has differing opinions about potential winners, driven by both emotional reactions and humor.
tinyllama:1.1b: The film industry is experiencing a slump in awards shows such as the Oscars due to excessive television coverage and an overabundance of celebrity endorsements.
Many film critics believe that these awards are becoming too similar to the Grammy music awards, with unsurprisingly few surprises left by the time of the ceremony.

Despite this, some Hollywood insiders still predict Eastwood's Million Dollar Baby will outshine Avatar and win best film and director, while Oscar voters tend to vote with their hearts rather than their heads.
Nevertheless, award shows are expected to continue as a way to boost box office sales and interest for films, regardless of who wins.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The US entertainment industry seems to be going through a period of intense scrutiny in relation to its most prestigious awards ceremonies, with concerns over their relevance and influence on the industry as a whole.
This comes amidst the criticism directed at Hollywood's handling of recent blockbuster films and the perceived lack of originality and innovation within mainstream cinema.
The Oscars have long been criticised for perpetuating an image of American culture that has devalued black actors, with many fans losing interest in movies that do not feature them.
This year's nominations seem to be no exception, with a number of high-profile snubs and wins alike prompting discussions about the relevance of these events in today's cultural landscape.
Despite these criticisms, the Oscars ceremony remains an important event for many within the film industry.
Awards can provide both accolades and commercial success for films and actors, and they offer a platform for celebrities to connect with audiences through speeches and performances.
However, it seems increasingly that this popularity is not translating into increased interest or excitement in cinema as a whole.
The recent Grammy music awards proved to be a ratings loser, and it seems the Oscars are facing the same issue.
This could be due to the lack of innovation and originality within some films, or a belief that certain categories are no longer relevant to the current industry.
The near constant flow of US film awards, representing directors, actors and producers' guilds, also seems to have generated very little excitement outside of the industry.
As for the potential winner of this year's Oscars, there is a wide range of possibilities among the various categories.
The best actor category appears to be dominated by the stars of Saving Private Ryan, with Ray star Jamie Foxx expected to win.
However, there are other contenders such as Leonardo DiCaprio from Martin Scorsese's masterpiece The Aviator, which was nominated for Best Picture.
Other notable nominees include Emma Stone from Clint Eastwood's Million Dollar Baby and Jodie Foster for The Silence of the Lambs.

The Screen International US editor Mike Goodridge believes that 2004's films have not grabbed the public's imagination, with many viewers turning their attention to other aspects of popular culture such as music and fashion.
This could be a result of the impact of 9/11 on America, but it also suggests that audiences are looking for something new and exciting to watch.
In conclusion, while the Oscars may have a certain charm and prestige, it is clear that they do not hold as much importance in the wider cultural landscape as they once did.

There is a growing need for entertainment that resonates with audiences on a larger scale, and this could ultimately lead to a shift in focus towards smaller, independent films that can captivate both critics and audiences alike.

Bob Strauss from the LA Daily News believes there are just too many awards shows, calling them "celebrity love-ins".
The recent Grammy music awards proved to be a ratings loser, and it seems Oscars organizers are determined not to go the same way.
Recent announced changes to the ceremony include lining up all five nominees on stage before announcing the winner.

The press speculated that the changes were aimed at boosting flagging advertising revenue, but Dave Karger from Entertainment Weekly maintained that the Oscars only generated excitement outside the industry when a blockbuster was nominated.
However, he pointed out that nearly constant US film awards have resulted in few surprises by the time the Oscar ceremony is upon us.
The Los Angeles Times and Los Angeles Daily News have primarily focused on industry-related news, while Variety and Hollywood Reporter keep their focus on entertainment news.

On Thursday, the Times simply printed a picture of the plastic tents going up outside the Kodak Theatre to protect the red carpet from rain, and in the UK, bets have closed on the best actor category, with Ray star Jamie Foxx a dead cert to win.

Screen International'S US editor Mike Goodridge thinks that films in 2004 have not grabbed the public's imagination, and people did not adore Saving Private Ryan like they usually do, despite it making a ton of money.

As to whether Rock could make an impact on the awards, the critics were not hopeful, with Mike Goodridge suggesting that his humour might prompt America's conservative states to turn off their televisions.
Despite this, there are still some optimistic views about the Oscars.
Mike Karger believes Clint Eastwood's Million Dollar Baby affected people emotionally, which is why it will beat Aviator, which was about technical artistry not feelings.
Eastwood has it in the bag, he said.
Similarly, Dave Karger thinks that awards should be less about ratings and more about big films affecting people emotionally, like Eastwood's Million Dollar Baby.
Mike Goodridge thinks best film and director are between Martin Scorsese's Aviator and Million Dollar Baby.

However, all three critics agree that award shows in general can be better, with some suggesting that they take a cue from the Grammy music awards by focusing more on entertainment news and less on industry-related stories.
